message: Short sleep makes your brain more threat-sensitive and less mood-stable today.
action: Do a 10–20 min outdoor light walk (easy pace).
why: After a short night, circadian timing + stress chemistry skew harder. Morning light anchors cortisol/melatonin timing and can blunt the “everything feels heavier” effect by stabilizing arousal and mood regulation.

message: Your circadian clock may be drifting later — you’ll feel alert late and sleepy late.
action: Get outdoor light within 60 min of waking; caffeine cutoff 2pm.
why: A later mid-sleep midpoint often tracks circadian delay. Early light pulls the clock earlier, while late caffeine blocks adenosine (sleep pressure) and makes the clock drift even more.

message: Low movement + low mood is a known “energy trap” combo.
action: Walk 5–10 min briskly (enough to warm up).
why: Even short movement bumps norepinephrine/endorphins and increases “action readiness.” The goal isn’t fitness — it’s flipping your state so starting the next task feels less impossible.

message: Extra-long sleep can increase sleep inertia — groggy body, slow brain.
action: 30–60 sec cool water + 2–3 min outdoor light.
why: If you wake from deeper sleep, inertia spikes. Light hits the wake circuits fast; a brief cold cue increases arousal tone and helps your brain exit the “still asleep” state.

message: When mood trends down, gentle connection can act like a stabilizer.
action: Send one 10-word check-in text to a safe person.
why: Low-effort connection reduces isolation load without demanding a big social plan. It’s often enough to reduce stress reactivity and nudge mood back toward baseline.

message: Stress + short sleep can lock you into high-arousal mode.
action: Do 3 rounds of 4–7–8 breathing (slow exhale).
why: Long exhales are a reliable parasympathetic cue (vagus). When fatigue removes your buffer, breathing is one of the fastest ways to downshift arousal without needing motivation.

message: You’re running a strong streak — that’s real leverage.
action: Lock it in: protect the next dose time exactly like this week.
why: High adherence works because it’s automatic: fewer decisions, fewer misses. Repeating the same cue keeps the habit loop stable.

message: Minor drift usually means the cue isn’t consistent enough yet.
action: Choose ONE anchor today: teeth / first meal / coffee / shower.
why: Habit anchors beat willpower. A reliable cue triggers action even when motivation is low.

message: Rebuilding starts with one clean win: the next dose.
action: Pick the next dose time now — simplest repeatable plan wins.
why: When consistency is low, complexity kills follow-through. One repeatable anchor rebuilds the loop faster than a perfect plan.

message: Very low mood can narrow attention and shut down drive.
action: Log 1 sentence: “Last hour: ___ / Trigger: ___.”
why: When mood is very low, memory becomes biased. Capturing context now improves pattern detection later and makes future insights more accurate.

message: Below baseline often means your system is carrying hidden load.
action: 2-minute reset: water + 60 sec movement (any).
why: Small state changes are the fastest way to reduce perceived effort. You’re not “fixing mood” — you’re lowering the friction to function.

message: Above baseline is a window — your brain is flagging this as “works.”
action: Write ONE thing that helped (a single tag).
why: Capturing the winning condition makes it repeatable. You’re training your system: “this is what good looks like.”

message: Mood trend is dipping — recovery debt may be building.
action: Schedule one recovery block tonight (30–60 min) and name it.
why: Recovery works better when it’s predictable. Naming + timing it reduces decision fatigue and stabilizes the next day more than random coping.

message: After stress, motivation can feel like it “switches off.” That’s normal chemistry.
action: Do one 2-minute quick-win task (tiny but finishable).
why: Stress pushes effort costs up. Tiny completions provide immediate reward signal and reduce the activation energy for the next step.

message: Mood trend is rising — momentum is a real resource.
action: Repeat tomorrow’s anchor habit (same time, same cue).
why: When momentum is up, consistency compounds. Repeating the cue that preceded the uptrend increases the chance you keep the slope.

message: Stress signals are up — arousal can crowd out calm focus.
action: 60 seconds: inhale normal, exhale slow (6 cycles).
why: Extending the exhale is a direct lever on arousal. It’s a fast way to regain cognitive control when stress is elevated.

message: No tags yet — tags are how insights become personal instead of generic.
action: Next check-in: add one tag (stressed / calm / focused / social / training).
why: Tags improve signal quality. Better signals → better matching → insights that feel like “yeah, that’s exactly it.”

message: Your 7-day average sleep is low — that’s chronic sleep debt, not just a bad night.
action: Tonight: set a “lights-dim” start time 45 min before bed.
why: Chronic debt raises baseline stress chemistry and lowers emotional buffer. A consistent wind-down cue helps melatonin timing and makes sleep easier to initiate.

message: You got short sleep but mood is holding — protect it with one smart move.
action: Avoid a long nap: if needed, cap at 15–20 min before 3pm.
why: Long or late naps reduce adenosine sleep pressure and can shift your clock later. A short early nap helps without stealing tonight’s sleep.

message: Your sleep timing may be shifting earlier — you might feel sleepy earlier and wake early.
action: Get evening light (10–15 min) and avoid very early bedtime.
why: Light in the evening nudges the clock later (opposite of morning light). If you keep going to bed too early, the early-wake pattern can lock in.

message: Low sleep + low movement often creates a “flat day” (low drive, low spark).
action: Do a 7-minute walk outside — no phone, just movement.
why: Sleep debt lowers buffer; low movement keeps arousal too low to initiate tasks. A short walk can increase norepinephrine/endorphins and make action feel easier.

message: Trend down + stressed tag suggests load is accumulating, not random mood noise.
action: Pick ONE relief lever tonight: early shutdown OR a short decompression walk.
why: When stress stays high, the brain shifts into protection mode (higher effort cost). One consistent recovery lever reduces the load more than scattered coping.

message: Low adherence + low mood usually means the plan has too much friction right now.
action: Shrink the plan: choose one anchor + one reminder (that’s it).
why: When mood is low, executive function is lower. Reducing steps (cue + single reminder) restores follow-through better than adding pressure.

message: Sleep improves fastest when wake time stays anchored (even after a bad night).
action: Get 2–5 min outdoor light within 60 min of waking.
why: Morning light is the strongest circadian cue. It stabilizes melatonin timing and makes sleep pressure build more predictably.

message: Mood gets clearer when you capture context, not just a number.
action: Write one line: “Right now I feel ___ because ___.”
why: A tiny reflection increases signal quality and helps future insights become more specific (less generic).

message: Consistency is easiest when a dose is tied to a cue, not motivation.
action: Pick one anchor: teeth / first meal / coffee / shower.
why: A reliable cue runs the habit loop automatically, even on low-energy days.

message: Momentum is built, not found — tiny wins create traction.
action: Do one 2-minute task now (timer on; finish one thing).
why: Small completions reduce perceived effort for the next step and restore a sense of control quickly.

message: A 60-second reset can change the next hour.
action: 6 slow breaths with long exhales.
why: Breath is the fastest lever you can pull without setup — it directly shifts arousal.

message: Hydration gaps can masquerade as “mystery fatigue.”
action: Drink a glass of water now.
why: Even mild dehydration can reduce concentration and increase perceived effort — especially with stress or heat.
